content.question: A <math alttext="chi square" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> goodness-of-fit test was used to test the hypothesis that students at a local university select majors in the same proportions as other universities in the state. A chi-square test statistic of <math alttext="chi square equals 45.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>45.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was calculated with a corresponding <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of 0.005. Which of the following is correct?

choices.label: There is sufficient evidence to conclude that students at the local university do not select majors in the same proportions as do students in the rest of the state.
There is sufficient evidence to conclude that students at the local university select majors in the same proportions as do students in the rest of the state.
There is insufficient evidence to conclude that students at the local university do not select majors in the same proportions as do students in the rest of the state.
There is insufficient evidence to conclude that students at the local university select majors in the same proportions as do students in the rest of the state.
Students at the local university select majors in the same proportions as do students in the rest of the state.

content.answer: There is sufficient evidence to conclude that students at the local university do not select majors in the same proportions as do students in the rest of the state.
